title: Cross-Border Publishing: Lessons From Neteaseâ€™s Once Human

rawLines.text: [Music]
Welcome to the Navit Gaming Podcast,
where it is our mission to explore the
business and future of video games. We
bring together the industry's brightest
builders, investors, and thinkers to
keep a pulse on current events, dissect
emerging trends and games, share lessons
learned, and have a great time.
This podcast is also part of Navik's
growing ecosystem which ranges from free
and premium research to consulting and
advisory services. For more information,
visit
[Music]
www.navic.co. This episode is brought to
you by Neon. For the first time in our
industry, developers can finally have
their own DTOC channels to save on app
store fees and build closer
relationships with players. But there's
a catch. Selling direct means either
building complex infrastructure yourself
or choosing among legacy providers whose
inexperience in games or questionable
reputations pose real risk to your
business. Luckily, there's Neon, the
DTOC platform built for games. As a
merchant of record with customizable web
shops optimized for conversion and
modern APIs that let you use your
existing live ops tools, Neon is trusted
by some of the biggest names in gaming
to help you sell direct without the
typical overhead. To start selling
direct and finally take control over
your full player experience, simply head
to
neonpay.com or check out the link in the
show notes. And with that, let's jump
into the episode. All right, what's up
everyone and welcome to the Navic Gaming
podcast. I'm your host Alex and this is
the interview and insight segment. Today
we're going to do an expose on
distribution and go to market in the
context of crossber development and
deployment. We've seen over the past
years a growing prevalence of Chinese
gaming companies growing in consumer
market share in the west and around the
globe. China itself is the largest
domestic market for gaming. First in
mobile, but now actually on PC. And
Chinese exports have grown in market
share. First again on mobile, but now
also on PC and console. Our most recent
favorite example is of course Blackmith
Wukong. And although the majority of
sales for this game were within China's
borders itself, it's a testament to how,
you know, the far-reaching length of
Chinese IP in even into the West. A
similar but different example is the
success of Marvel Rivals which is
predominantly made by Netis though it
may utilize um a western IP. So today
we're going to have a discussion about
China's evolving game market but more
specifically as Chinese mobile
developers now capture around 50% of the
global gaming market discussing
publishing owned and operated Chinese IP
in the west. And to do that we're going
to talk about Netis and specifically
Once Human. Once Human is a PC survival
game developed by Star Studio, a
subsidiary of Netis that launched in
July 2024 into early access on Steam to
fairly acclaimed success as a
free-to-play live service game. It hit
an all-time peak CCU of 231K and on
average as the time of writing. Um, and
it hit around 20 to 30K CCU for rolling
30-day averages um about one week ago
once Human launched a mobile version on
iOS and Android. And this version is
also crossplatform and cross region. And
so I'm delighted to welcome my guest
today to talk about all of this. Um my
guest is Derek Hugh. Um head of
operations at the overseas market at
NEIS. Um he spent four years at Garina
before joining Netis where he focused on
